user.biography:
Artist, NatGeo Fellow, photographer and filmmaker. Professional speaker. Environmentalist. 
Artist duo Alexandrov Klum

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on August 05, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial, and @alexandrovklumofficial. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
While diving or snorkeling in the Galapagos you can easily bumb in to marine iguanas like this one. The marine iguana can be found only on the Galápagos Islands and it has the ability, unique among modern lizards, to forage in the sea, making it a marine reptile. The marine iguanas are sometimes dangerously cold after grazing algae at dephts down to nearly 10 meters (30 or more feet). Shot on assignment for @natgeo 
Please check out @alexandrovklumofficial to learn more about our current art projects and our upcoming road trip in Sweden.  #galapagos #cool #cold #mattiasklum #marineiguana #conservation #protectouroceans #protectbiodiversity @natgeo @thephotosociety @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial

node.text: We are so excited to go on a @alexandrovklumofficial road trip in lovely Sweden. Working on new exhibitions and art shows,  visiting new venues and of course some friends along the way! #protectbiodiversity #artistduoalexandrovklum #ceroemissionsroadtrip #eqc #mbfamily #sweden #art @irisalexandrov @swedense @alexandrovklumofficial

node.text: Love the camouflage and the gorgeous eyes of this funky creature! I photographed this crocodile fish during a night dive in Raja Ampat, an archipelago off the northwestern tip of West Papua,  Indonesia. One of the richest marine ecosystems on Earth. #rajaampat #saveouroceans #conservation #protectbiodiversity #goldentriangle @natgeo @alexandrovklumofficial @irisalexandrov @thephotosociety

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on July 16, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial. May be an image of snake and nature.

node.text:
An African Tree viper (Atheris sp.) will here represent snakes near and far because today is #worldsnakeday !!! As pretty as they come, this nocturnal arboreal viper feeds on frogs, lizards, birds etc. The fact that it's a viper means that it has a long mobile fang that can swing forward when the snake strikes. I took this photograph in the beautiful rainforest of Nouabal-Ndoki National Park in the Republic of the Congo for @natgeo 
Please check out @alexandrovklumofficial to learn about our art projects! #republicofthecongo #protectbiodiversity #mattiasklum #livingthedream #ndoki #artistduoalexandrovklum @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial @thephotosociety @natgeo

node.text: Today it’s #sharkawarenessday !  I’m honoring this by reposting a sequence from our film Vamizi -Cradle of Coral.  A beautiful pack of gray reef sharks on the prowl on Neptune's Arm,  near Vamizi, the largest island in the Quirimbas Archipelago. Its relative isolation from mainland Mozambique has preserved Vamizi’s natural beauty and wildlife. It has magnificent coral reefs and is a unique breeding ground for whales, dolphins, turtles and and not least the endangered gray reef sharks. Please go to @alexandrovklumofficial to see other images from Vamizi and to learn more about our international projects! #friendsofvamizi #vamizi #artistduoalexandrovklum #vamiziisland #oceanconservation #protectbiodiversity @natgeo @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on July 12, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
The beautiful textile cone snail is one of the most venomous creatures on the planet. Several human deaths have been attributed to this species. Their venom, a complex concoction of hundreds of different toxins, is delivered via a harpoonlike tooth propelled from an extendable proboscis (seen vaguely in this picture). There is no antivenin for a cone snail sting, and treatment is limited to merely keeping victims alive until the toxins wear off.
Just because human deaths are fairly uncommon, it doesn't mean you shouldn’t be cautious. A few microliters of cone snail toxin is powerful enough to kill a bunch of people.
The incredibly toxic venom of this species has to be strong enough to instantly paralyze. Otherwise, the lunch would swim away to die, and the slow-moving snail would end up with nothing. 
Ironically, among the compounds found in cone snail venom are proteins which, when isolated, have enormous potential as pain-killing drugs. Research shows that certain of these proteins target specific human pain receptors and can be up to 10,000 times more potent than morphine without morphine 's addictive properties and side-effects. #lovescience #conesnail #protectbiodiversity #fiji #mattiasaklum @natgeo @thephotosociety @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mattias A. Klum on July 09, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: A Galapagos marine iguana posing like a statue of stone in the late evening. Scientists figure that land-dwelling iguanas from South America must have drifted out to sea millions of years ago on logs or other debris, eventually landing on the Galápagos. From that species emerged marine iguanas, which spread to nearly all the islands of the archipelago. Each island hosts marine iguanas of unique size, shape and color, like these beauties. Shot on assignment on the Galapagos Islands, Ecuador for @natgeo. Check out @alexandrovklumofficial to learn more about our current art projects! #themarineiguanas #protectbiodiversity #galapagos #darwin #conservation #mattiasklum @natgeo @thephotosociety @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on June 27, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial. May be an image of nature.

node.text: I took this photograph during a @natgeo assignment in the Republic of Congo. My life as a photographer and filmmaker has given me a very diversified and rarely uneventful life. I am also frequently fortunate enough to work with wonderful and skilled people. In this case shooting (with a camera) the highly venomous and extremely rare water cobra, I really wouldn’t have managed so well without the kind assistance from Samuel, (my camera assistant at the time) and Zoltan (a great herpethologist). By protecting rainforests and other ecosystems as well as their inhabitants and by using natures wealth sustainably we secure a healthier planet and future for humanity! Please also go to @alexandrovklumofficial to follow our current art projects from around the world as well more everyday stuff. #grateful #teamwork #determination #respectnature #watercobra #congo #cobra #snake #conservation #rainforest #respect #artistduoalexandrovklum #bestjobintheworld @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial @thephotosociety @natgeo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on June 21, 2021 tagging @irisalexandrov, @mattiasklumofficial, and @alexandrovklumofficial. May be an image of tree, nature and body of water.

node.text:
A took this water mirror in Tomelilla, Skåne, Sweden. Photographed together with my artist partner and love @irisalexandrov 
This particular project highlighted water scarcity issues and the importance of maintaining healthy ecosystems and watersheds in Sweden, to be able to secure access to to clean tap water now and in the future. This is obviously a global issue and dilemma. All life needs water. It is the world’s most precious resource, fueling everything from the food you eat, to the cotton you wear, to the energy you depend upon every day. Freshwater habitats—such as lakes, rivers, streams, wetlands and aquifers—house an incredible proportion of the world’s biodiversity: more than 10% of all known animals and about 50% of all known fish species. Yet despite the massive role water plays for people and nature, it is a surprisingly finite resource. Less than 1% of the world's water is accessible to humans. #protectbiodiversity #freshwater  @irisalexandrov @thephotosociety @natgeo @alexandrovklumofficial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on June 18, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial. May be a closeup.

node.text:
What creature does this beautiful eye belong to? Can you guess? Coral reefs like in Indonesia’s remarkable Raja Ampat is overwhelmingly rich in life forms. In fact, it’s one of the richest marine ecosystems in the entire World. The reefs below the surface are home to more than 1500 species of fish (including the funky species that I photographed in a cave) and around 700 species of reef-building coral, and counting...! 
 By preserving and respecting the remaining beauty on this planet we actually secure long term sustainable success for humankind! The only safe path ahead is to use (and love) nature in a much more responsible and thoughtful way, anchored in science and "common sense"! #goldeneye #rajaampat #indonesia #marine #ecosystem #paradise  #divers  #protectbiodiversity #mattiasklum  #conservation @natgeo @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial @thephotosociety @mattiasklumofficial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mattias A. Klum on June 13, 2021 tagging @mattiasklumofficial. May be a closeup of emu and nature.

node.text:
The hoatzin or stinkbird is a tropical bird species found in swamps and mangroves of the Amazon and the Orinoco Delta in South America. It is famous for having chicks that possess claws on two of their wing digits. I have on many occasions seen the fledglings use their claws to hold on to twigs and branches which looks like something straight out of a Jurassic Park movie.

It's a very noisy bird, with a variety of hoarse groans, hisses, croaks and grunts. Calls are used to maintain contact between group members, warn of  intruders and by chicks and fledglings begging for food.
Quite recent research indicates that the hoatzin is the last surviving member of a bird line that branched off in its own direction some 64 million years ago, shortly after the extinction event that killed the non-avian dinosaurs. This make the stink bird or hoatzin the oldest living line of birds, as the last common ancestor of the remaining birds are all younger!

This remarkable bird is not considered endangered. Its survival seems to be more assured than that of many other endemic bird species of its range. In Brazil, indigenous peoples only infrequently collect the eggs for food, and the adults are occasionally hunted, but in general this is rare, as the stink bird or hoatzin is reputed to taste... like it smells...
The hoatzin is the national bird of Guyana. #stinkbird #hoatzin #science #mattiasklum #rainforest #mangrove #funky @alexandrovklumofficial @natgeo @irisalexandrov @thephotosociety

node.text:
Today is World Oceans Day!! The ocean is a planetary superpower. Home to spectacular ecosystems and remarkable wildlife, the ocean covers 71% of our Earth’s surface and sustains the lives of billions of people. It regulates our climate, produces half the oxygen we breathe, and fuels the water cycle that produces rain and freshwater.
This short film shows some manta rays gliding inches over me and my camera in Indonesia's Raja Ampat. Mantas are filter feeders and eat large quantities of zooplankton, which they swallow with their open mouths as they swim. Mantas visit cleaning stations for the removal of parasites like in this short film. The largest mantas can reach 1,350 kg (2,980 lb) and at least 7 m (23 ft) in "wingspan". In 2014, Indonesia brought in a fishing and export ban as it realized that manta ray tourism is more economically beneficial than allowing the fish to be killed. A dead manta is worth $50 to $600 while manta ray tourism can bring in $1 million during the life of a single manta ray. Indonesia has 2.2 million square miles of ocean and this is now the world's largest sanctuary for manta rays. Mantas have one of the highest brain-to-body mass ratios of all fish and if approached with care and respect they can be curious and spend a long time with you. The coral reefs of Raja Ampat are some of the richest marine habitats on Earth. Let's protect Raja Ampat and other fragile marine ecosystems! #thecoraleden #mantaray #rajaampat #indonesia #marine #worldoceansday #ecosystem #protectbiodiversiry #paradise #divers  #mattiasklum #wwf #iucn #conservation @natgeo @irisalexandrov @alexandrovklumofficial @thephotosociety
